bibl.title: Letter from Jennie Wilson to Howard A. Kelly, March 2, 1907

div1.p: Wilson relays Kissinger's situation to Kelly.

div1.head: Letter from Jennie Wilson to Howard A. Kelly, March 2, 1907
div1.opener:
So. Whitley, Ind. Mar. 2, 1907
Howard Kelly, M.D.
Baltimore, Md.
My dear Sir,
div1.p:
Your letter relating to
John R. Kissinger received.

You are mistaken in
thinking he now resides here,
as his home has been in South
Bend, Ind. more than two
years, and that is more than
sixty miles from here.

When I read your article in
“The Youth's Companion” I sent
it to Kissinger, and I am sending
you the letter he wrote in reply,

He is not as well as he was,
and is now unable to help with
the washing.

You will see in the letter that
his physician knows you, but I
do not know his name.

Kissinger would be delighted
to have your book and Dr.
Reed's picture, I am sure,
and if you write to him, his
address is given at the close of
his letter, you can have him
tell you who his physician
is and then have him see about
the pictures. I think Kissing-
er had some good ones made
just after leaving the army,
and some could be made
of him in his wheel-chair.

As to his being a Christian
I fear he is not, unless the
change has come recently.

He was almost broken-hearted
when first stricken down.

The prospect that he will
be pensioned seems brighter
now, I am told.

When writing to him, please
do not tell him I sent you his
letter to me, he might not like it,

I know how to sympathize
with him, as I am confined
to a wheel-chair myself.
